pullRequest.body:
`Unitization ùïú A` is equipped with a norm when `A` is a `RegularNormedAlgebra`, and it turns out that norm is minimal among all norms for which the natural coercion from `A` is an isometry and which satisfy `‚Äñ1‚Äñ = 1`.

There is also a maximal norm, given by `‚Äñx‚Äñ := ‚Äñx.fst‚Äñ + ‚Äñx.snd‚Äñ`, and this norm also makes sense even when `A` is not a `RegularNormedAlgebra`. We place this norm on the type synonym `WithLp 1 (Unitization ùïú A)`.

---

bors d+
Could you include the name of the instance here?

```suggestion
One application of this is a straightforward proof that the quasispectrum of an element in a
```
Perhaps worth a note somewhere that `TrivSqZeroExt` has the same instance available without a type synonym. (and perhaps in the other direction talking about Unitization`)
I think this should be found automatically from the general `WithLp` infrastructure?
Ah, indeed. I got tricked because there was no `Algebra` instance, but it's obvious why there isn't one of those.
I think this should exist in the generality of arbitrary algebras? Is there any case where `WithLp 1 A` would be expected to have a different multiplication than `A`?
Sure, there are examples. Consider convolution on $L^1$.
Would you expect convolution to be the *default* there though? Or would that be `WithConvolution (WithLp 1 A)`?

Personally, I would expect it to be the default, but maybe I'm an outlier. 

My inclination would be to worry about generalizing this (the `AlgEquiv`) when we have another example where we want it.
For what it's worth, I would be *very* surprised to see convolution as the default multiplication on `WithLp 1 A`! In any case, I think generalizing can wait until we have a use case for it.

```suggestion
One application of this is a straightforward proof that the quasispectrum of an element in a
non-unital Banach algebra is compact, which can be established by passing to the unitization.
-/
```
